body.p: we concluded (based on the small p-value of 0.012) that the data provide fairly strong evidence of a moderately weak linear relationship between cry count soon after birth and IQ and age 3.
We would now like to consider using the least squares regression line for predicting IQ at age 3 based on cry count soon after birth. Plot the least squares regression line on the scatterplot:

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To open R with the data set preloaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in R.
The data have been loaded into the data frame baby. Enter the command baby to see the data. The two variables in the data frame are cry.count and IQ.
Let's rerun the previous Learn by Doing code to acquire the plot and equation.

li.code: plot(baby$cry.count,baby$IQ, xlab="Number of Crying Events", ylab="IQ")

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions

ul.li: Choose: Stat → Regression → Simple Linear
Select explanatory and response variables
Press Compute!

alternative.p: The fitted line plot will be on the second page of the output. (Press Next to see it).

ul.li: Choose: Stat → Regression → Fitted Line Plot.
Enter the response and explanatory variables.
Click "OK."

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To open the dataset, click here to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel. When Excel opens you may have to enable editing.

ul.li: Select all of the data in columns A and B, and then choose Scatter in the Charts group on the Insert tab (click on the picture of the scatterplot).
Choose the first scatterplot option (Scatter with only Markers). Now we have a scatterplot.
Right-click on one of the data points in the scatterplot, and choose Add Trendline from the pop-up menu.
Make sure that Trendline Options is selected on the left, and then choose Linear under Trend/Regression type.
At the bottom of the window, make sure that Display Equation on chart and Display R-squared value on chart are checked.
Click Close.

alternative.title: TI Instructions

p.em: Linear Regression Line (Line of Best Fit)—plot on scatterplot

ul.li:
The TI calculator stores the last regression line that you calculated until you calculate another one. If the last correlation, linear regression t-test, and StatPlot you did with your TI were for this example, skip the next two steps. Otherwise:
Follow TI instructions to display a Scatterplot. (Learn by Doing Case Q→Q (2 of 3) first one on the page)
Follow TI directions for Correlation (Learn by Doing Case Q→Q (2 of 3) first one on the page) OR Linear Regression T-Test (Learn by Doing Case Q→Q (2 of 3) second one on the page). Either of these calculate the regression line.
Choose y=
Now cut and paste the values for a and b.

To get the y-intercept (a):
Choose VARS/5:Statistics.
Choose EQ (right arrow twice).
Choose 2:a
Press the + button.

To get the slope (b):
Choose VARS/5:Statistics.
Choose EQ (right arrow twice).
Choose 3:b.
Press the X,T, Θ, n button.

alternative.p: Note: As long as you don’t change Y1, each time you find another regression line, a and b will automatically save the new values and the new line will be graphed.
You can toggle Y1 on and off. When the = is highlighted, the graph is ON. To turn it OFF, use the left arrow to highlight the =, then press ENTER. Repeat to turn graph back on.
If you’ve set up the scatterplot and set up Y1=, you can ZOOM/9:ZoomStat to see the regression line plotted on the scatterplot.
You should see a graph window with the scatterplot and the regression plotted on it.

p.em: Linear Regression Line (Line of Best Fit)—use for predictions

alternative.p: Method 1: (low tech) Write down the a (y-intercept) and b (slope) values for the regression line (y = a + bx).

ul.li: To find the predicted y-value for any x, simply add the value of a plus the value of b times x.
Note: Remember order of operations. Multiplication comes before addition. If you use your TI, the TI follows the standard order of operations. However, it is wrong to use:
a + b ENTER
* x ENTER
This will force the addition to be performed before the multiplication, which is incorrect.

alternative.p: Method 2: If you’ve set Y1 = a + bx.

ul.li: Be sure Y1 is turned ON (= sign will be highlighted. If not, left arrow till = is highlighted and press ENTER.)
Go to a home screen (press 2ND/QUIT).
Choose Y1 (VARS/Y-VARS/1:Function/1:Y1).
Press left parenthesis, the x-value, right parenthesis.
For example, to find the predicted y-value when x is 25, we want Y1(25).
Press ENTER.
